title: Are the Dropkick Murphys as popular in Ireland as they are with the Irish American community in Boston? - Quora

response.answer_text: No, they are good Irish-American band, but they are definately more popular in the US than they would be amongst the Irish themselves. Its something that always amused me when I would visit my family in Canada, and go to the local ‘Irish’ pub, was the music played, plenty of the likes of Flogging Molly and Dropkick Murphy’s, but very few actual songs from contemporary Irish bands. Here in Ireland they would be known be a good minority of people. The last time they played a gig of their own as far as I know, they played in the Vicar Street Venue that has a capacity of between 1000–1500 people, they had a sell out crowd on the Saturday night, don’t know about the sunday. I like a fair bit of their stuff, but actually more for their left wing politics than their Irishness.

One of their songs (their version of Shipping Up To Boston) was the intro to The Departed, and lots of people have seen that movie. I think on average most people who’ve heard of them have heard of them because of that. The market for the kind of Irish-American Oirishness that the DMs produce is much bigger in America than in Ireland, though.

I've never been to Boston myself, but within Ireland they aren't particularly popular. Now, that isn't to say they're unpopular, they're just not a band that anyone would ever play, unless they were feeling particularly patriotic.

Nope. Never heard of them and their name has never come up in any discussions with friends. It’s possible they might be known about, but it would definitely be a minor following…AFAIK they have never toured Ireland (certain not outside of Dublin) though they probably do the odd date in Dublin at smaller venues.
Eh, no. I’ve never heard of them. I don’t know who/what they are so my guess is they are not widely known.
